Custom engine in The Witness game

29 Sep 2013

Recently I had a twitter conversation with Jonathan Blow, the creator of Braid and leader of the team behind the upcoming game The Witness. I was wondering why developers decided to use custom engine in their project, considering many good engines already available out there.

Jonathan spoke of the following reasons:

  • You have full control of your code
  • You have no restrictions
  • You can achieve any level of quality you wish (clearly because of 1. and 2.)
  • You owe no money to anyone whose commercial engine you might have been using

These are good points, however they shouldn’t be considered as a 100% guide for you to go and roll your own engine. Do that only if you really need to, if other engines don’t provide you with the necessary tools. Sadly, there were no technical details discussed about what was actually impossible to achieve with existing engines when developing The Witness. Hopefully we’ll hear about it from developers in the future.

Below is the conversation:

@0xc0dec Because what engine are you going to do this game in?

— Jonathan Blow (@Jonathan_Blow) September 28, 2013

@Jonathan_Blow OGRE, Unity, Unreal, whatever... just wanted to know why custom engine is better for you than any other engine out there :)

— Aleksey Fedotov (@0xc0dec) September 28, 2013

@0xc0dec When you want to do technically challenging things that other engines don't do already, you roll your own.

— Jonathan Blow (@Jonathan_Blow) September 29, 2013

@0xc0dec Also, when you want full control of your source code to maximize feel / minimize porting badness / etc, you roll your own.

— Jonathan Blow (@Jonathan_Blow) September 29, 2013

@Jonathan_Blow it's a good reason,however rolling custom engine is usually way more time-consuming than implementing things in other engines

— Aleksey Fedotov (@0xc0dec) September 29, 2013

@0xc0dec This seems true, but actually often it is not -- because you don't control all the code of the other engine, it may be difficult

— Jonathan Blow (@Jonathan_Blow) September 29, 2013

@0xc0dec or impossible to reach the same quality threshold, and you end up fighting a lot of fires that you would not in your own code.

— Jonathan Blow (@Jonathan_Blow) September 29, 2013

@0xc0dec Plus, once you have your own engine, that is a valuable asset that most developers these days do not have.

— Jonathan Blow (@Jonathan_Blow) September 29, 2013

@0xc0dec (e.g. I do not want to pay Mark Rein 25% of all money I ever make because I used Unreal.)

— Jonathan Blow (@Jonathan_Blow) September 29, 2013

@0xc0dec Sure.

— Jonathan Blow (@Jonathan_Blow) September 29, 2013
